Clearly the weakest of the original Star Wars trilogy, Return of the Jedi is still a lot of fun. It has great performances, the father-son dynamic between Vader and Luke is given a satisfying conclusion, and the final confrontation with the Emperor is one of the most epic moments in film history worthy of a place alongside the final confrontation in the Empire Strikes Back. Unfortunately, Endor and its Ewok inhabitants, as iconic as they are, are not as engaging as the rest of the film. Furthermore, the first act of the movie is much the same, iconic but just not as engaging as the rest of the trilogy. Overall, Return of the Jedi is a solid conclusion to the trilogy, Luke‚Äôs journey to becoming a jedi, and Darth Vader‚Äôs story.

"Star Wars Episode VI: Return of the Jedi" delivers a thrilling conclusion to the original trilogy, seamlessly blending epic action with heartfelt character moments. Director Richard Marquand masterfully navigates the intricate plot, bringing closure to the saga's central conflicts while introducing captivating new elements. The film's visual effects continue to astound, particularly in the climactic battle sequences. Mark Hamill shines as Luke Skywalker, showcasing a newfound maturity and depth as he confronts his destiny. With its iconic moments, memorable performances, and resonant themes of redemption and hope, "Return of the Jedi" successfully brought closure to the series, while leaving room for future prequels and sequels to expand the Star Wars universe.

Star Wars: Return of the Jedi is the 3rd and final film in George Lucas' original Star Wars trilogy. Return of the Jedi won 5 Oscars (4 Oscars for visual/art and sound effects in addition to John Williams' 3rd Oscar for his Star Wars original scores!) from 1984's Academy Awards. Having grown up with Star Wars, maybe my earlier opinions of the previous SW movies are tainted by how young I was when I first saw A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back. The storytelling in Return of the Jedi feels like a rehashing of the first movie, and the battles between high tech and low tech camps are comically optimistic. The thing was made a little worse when Anakin was re-aged at the last moment we see him by Lucas, and the original is harder to find. Lucas' re-edits are understandable, but his wiping away the film history of his monumental Star Wars accomplishments (Oscars aside, many SW accomplishments) for the rest of us to enjoy has made me a little sad now and then. At 4 years old I was included on a "girls movie night" with my sister and my mother during the first theatrical run in our hometown of A New Hope. I've been a fan ever since. I like the poetry. I get that history may not repeat, but it definitely appears to rhyme. I understood all that by the time the prequels came to town. I'm grateful for this series, for all the stunningly choreographed lightsaber duels across the series, for the story about how Warwick Davis got his Star Wars toys, and for all the Light & Magic I got from this series over my lifetime! Return of the Jedi is a nearly perfect ending to a nearly perfect Science Fiction space opera. It's so good that I want more, but the story is over. What more could I possibly want from the Skywalker Saga?

As a die-hard Star Wars fan, I can confidently say that Return of the Jedi is the grand finale we all deserved! This epic conclusion to the original trilogy is a true masterpiece that solidifies Star Wars as the greatest sci-fi franchise in the galaxy! First things first, the witty banter and clever dialogues in Return of the Jedi had me grinning from ear to ear. Han Solo's snarky remarks and Luke Skywalker's Jedi quips were on point, adding that extra layer of entertainment to an already thrilling adventure. Who can forget the iconic line, "It's a trap!" delivered by Admiral Ackbar? Classic! Speaking of entertainment, Return of the Jedi delivers it in abundance. The epic space battles between the Rebel Alliance and the Galactic Empire had me on the edge of my seat, cheering for the Rebel fighters as they bravely took on the Death Star. And let's not forget the nerve-wracking lightsaber duel between Luke and Darth Vader, the ultimate clash of good versus evil. The action sequences in this film are nothing short of spectacular! What sets Return of the Jedi apart from many other sci-fi films is its ability to stand the test of time. Despite being released decades ago, the visual effects and practical craftsmanship hold up remarkably well. From the intricate creature designs to the breathtaking worlds like Endor and Tatooine, the attention to detail is simply astounding. It's a testament to the passion and dedication of the filmmakers that this movie continues to captivate audiences of all generations. In conclusion, Return of the Jedi deserves its place among the stars as an unforgettable and triumphant conclusion to the original Star Wars trilogy. With its witty dialogues, captivating action, and timeless appeal, this film proves why the Star Wars saga remains the pinnacle of science fiction. So, grab your lightsaber, don your Jedi robe, and embark on this galactic adventure that will transport you to a galaxy far, far away. May the Force be with you!

SPOILERS This final film in the original trilogy begings with Luke and the gang infiltrating Jabba's palace to free Han solo, who is still frozen in carbonite. Once Jabba is strangled by a sexy Princess Leia and all his goons fed to the Sarlacc, the team heads to destroy the Empire's second Death Star. Han and Leia must disable its protective shield on Endor, while Luke confronts his father and is emotionally manipulated by the Emperor. In the end, the second death star is blown up, Darth Vader, The Emperor and Yoda dead. While watching this movie I could not for the life of me get into it. It definitely felt its age more-so than the last two somehow. The green screen in the Sarlacc sequence, the close ups of Jabba's animatronic face, flying bike chases on Endor - I had such a hard time getting past the old time stamp embedded throughout the film. I didn't feel this way about the first two, not entirely sure what the difference was. Another aspect I felt seriously lacked in the film was emotional resonance and impact. The film was full of character moments trying to evoke emotion - Yoda dying, Han and Leia reuniting, Luke discovering the truth about his father and sister, confronting his father, battling within himself, the death of his father - I mean it seriously tried to be an emotionally powerful film. Unfortunately, none of these events got through to me. I honestly found myself laughing through most of them due to the corniness. I dont think anyone in the film did a great job acting these deep character moments, and most of them were just Hamill making a shocked face any five year old can make. Han solo is equipped with an arsenal of one liners this movie that seriously dont make his character relatable or personal in any way. Yoda's death is incredibly abrupt with almost no emphasis, and once again Hamill's acting this scene is less than good. The action sequences felt pretty lacklustre and failed to captivate me throughout. I really wanted to be invested in the final battle between Luke and his father. I just again, couldn't get past the corniness man. Luke is walking with him and referring to him as 'father', and Vader giving him some life lesson calling him 'son'. I just feel like the entire thing is overdramatized, like, this is NOT how you'd speak to someone you just found out is your father, and who is incredibly evil. Like I get hes his dad, but there is no relationship built up to this point, so the name calling feels, well, cringy. It just didn't work for me. I will however admit that Vader dying tugged at my heart a little, more than the rest of the movie anyway. Death stars really need to have better systems in place. I mean, this massive, inconceivably advanced technological marvel capable of destroying planets is being built in space, and can be blown up that easily? One shaft that is a strait shot to its core? Okay. Not to mention this plot point already happened two movies ago, and was done better. I can't help but feel the unwavering love for these original three films falls into the umbrella of nostalgia for most. Most people watch these movies as kids, and being old with less-than-stellar tech, there is something grounding and comforting about them - it takes us back to an older time. As we grow up, we hold onto the memories of love and fascination around the franchise, its characters and immense, intergalactic world. There is also no denying what Star Wars has done for Sci-Fi and films as a whole. It redefined its genre, and all movies after it, regardless of genre - it set a new benchmark in world building. The practical effects and early-stage VFX were revolutionary and captured the awe of audiences everywhere. They brought us some-of the most well known and loved fiction characters ever, and without going on, changed everything that came after. I have immense respect for these movies and what they have done culturally, technically and creatively, but all I'm saying is they may be a tad overrated. The quality of story in these movies is embellished due to its practical effects, VFX, world building, production design, eclectic characters and pioneering. Thats a good seg-way into the brilliance of the world design, set pieces and creativity involved. Throughout these films, the imagination of the different creatures and characters has captivated me, and I love the immense world created. The Sarlacc, Rancor, Jabba's minions, the Ewoks - and thats just to name a few this movie. The variety of planets is awesome, and I love how the story planet-hops, rather than stay stagnant. Its like space itself is our central hub, and the different planets are like different ships we are temporarily on. The sets created are extremely impressive and detailed, from the interior of spaceships to Jabba's palace. This franchise is an incredible and inventive space - story, and its an awesome premise to a franchise. The fact that most of it was done by hand is mind-blowing, wether it holds up today or not. Event though this film may not have been my favourite, I look forward to watching the next one. Overall, Return of the Jedi failed to capture my interest in terms of characters and story, but as always shines through imaginative creatures and production design. The practical effects and sets are mind-blowing, wether they hold up today or not.

40 years later and we all thought this was the end of the beloved, successful legacy of Star Wars George Lucas had envisioned 'A New Hope' got the ball rolling followed by 'Empire Strikes Back' that would build upon it The third entry directed by Richard Marquand in the original trilogy attempts to wrap up this story with the final battle between good and evil of the Rebel Alliance and the Galactic Empire Picking up after the previous film Luke Skywalker is about to become a Jedi knight with much more confidence and experience but first he must confront Darth Vader again whom he discovered was his actual father But he must also resist the dark temptations of the Emperor avoiding falling to the dark side of the Force lest he become an agent of evil Leia, Lando, Chewbacca, R2-D2, and C-3PO attempt to save Han Solo from the clutches of Jabba the Hutt The final confrontation finds our heroes taking out the generator shield for the second Death Star on the forest moon of Endor But they also get assistance from the locals called Ewoks who seem cute but are sharp toothed being they prefer nature based tactics as opposed to machines Many see this as lesser than the previous films as it goes for a more lighter, cutesty feel Plus the beginning taking too many detours and an over reliance on the Ewoks, the dialogue is also still kinda stilted This does has some of the best effects by Industrial Light & Magic from the speeder bike chase to the Ewok battle and the most dramatic moments though from Yoda passing to Leia finding out her sibling relationship to mainly between Luke and Vader constantly going back and forth about their paths they should take Their confrontation is physical but also psychological Ian McDiarmid is pitch perfect as the Emperor being so imposing, dark, delightfully sinister, and uses that right amount of seduction hungering for power spitting out hate and manipulation Plus the final battle more than makes up for the minor flaws with three battles going on simultaneously even if it feels a bit jumbled Fans also remember the appearance of Boba Fett unjustly tossed aside but thankfully we'd see him again in future projects John Williams' score always heightens the excitement and sells the emotions in the storytelling as usual 'Jedi' wraps up Luke's story completing his arc of his journey while also giving Vader his redemption making it one of the most iconic moments in the franchise‚Ä¶the once proud Jedi prophecized to bring balance truly returned True the action scenes are not as thrilling as before but it's more about emotional payoffs than anything for all the characters still retaining the swashbuckler feel Many of the themes still reside in loyalty, decency, redemption, self-sacrifice, friendship, and family for a fitting finale Little did we know this wouldn't be the end of the beloved franchise; Lucas and company forever made their mark in film, science-fiction, geek even thevpop cultural landscape, and modern filmmaking techniques thanks to ‚ÄòStar Wars‚Äô

I saw Return of the Jedi 40 years ago, when it was in theaters the first time. It was thought to be the conclusion of the Star Wars trilogy, and the end of a new era in film history. The film was good on that basis, although the least satisfying of the three original films. I am not sure anyone contemplated that the next 40 years would deliver a series of new and continuous projects around the Star Wars character and properties. This one held up. It is not the best or the worst of the Star Wars films. It has some great moments and some great emotional content. It held up on the big screen, and while there are not many changes or additions the film seems enhanced, rather than aged-so it looks good. Some of the Endor special effects are dated, but the rest is engaging and a fun time. It was nice to see it in a full audience with people that were not alive when the original series played on the big screen.

I think this was a great movie! However, there were a few things I didn't like. First, I think it was a big mistake (letdown) to remove Vader's mask, only to find a Mr. Potato head under there. I think Vader's look should have remained mysterious. Now when you see Vader making his entrance in New Hope it's not as ominous, scary, or mysterious. We did not have to know what Vader looked like under the mask. At best, they should've left his look under the mask mechanical, but even that would have ruined it. Also, Ben turned out to be a liar using deceptive tactics and language you would expect from the dark-side when he says "a certain point of view" nonsense. Well, from a "certain point of view", maybe the Emperor and Sith are right. Ben obviously thought Luke was old and mature enough to go to Alderaan with him, but not old and mature enough to know the truth. Also, I definitely missed Han and Chewie running the Falcon, but it is what it is. The music was great! John Williams is a master at what he does! One last thing, I never liked Jabba the Hutt. With all the talent and creativity at Lucas' disposal, I know they could've created something (or someone) much better. This movie is certainly better than Empire Strikes Back by a long shot. So, yes it's worth the price of a ticket. Go see it!

Massively overrated movie. Poor planning led to George Lucas creating about a million essential plot points that should have been established from the first or second movie. The "leia is my sister" line is the worst of the original 6 movies. I've watched all of them dozens of times, so I've pretty much memorized every scene of each movie. The Ewoks were the minions before there were minions, and the Death Star shouldn't have been reused. If you watch the movies 1-6, it's glaringly obvious that the choreography isn't nearly as good in this movie as it was in any of the prequels. In spite of all of this, it has many positive aspects. The final fight with Vader is one of the most emotional in Star Wars, and the final defeat of the emperor is oh so satisfying. Vader's redemption felt genuine, and the parallel between the rebellion's celebration and Luke mourning the death of his father is brilliant. For the time, the visual effects are extremely impressive, and it's easy to see why so many enjoyed it so thoroughly. Overall a satisfying -albeit flawed- conclusion to George Lucas' brilliant 6 movie saga. So glad some big company like Disney didn't go and buy it up and make 3 terrible sequels that ruined the first 6 that George Lucas carefully crafted, or something like that.

"Star Wars: Episode VI- Return of the Jedi" is a solid science fiction/adventure film but one that is not quite on the grand level of "Star Wars: Episode IV- A New Hope" (1977) and "Stars Wars: Episode V- The Empire Strikes Back" (1980) but one that is still a fitting conclusion to the original trilogy and the finale for the series as a whole. While the latter trilogy would come close to this level they never quite fit with the darker and more auspicious original trilogy in scope and atmosphere. Our primary protagonists see fitting ends to their stories here, Han Solo (Harrison Ford), Luke Skywalker (Mark Hamill), and Princess Leia (Carrie Fisher) all see their destinies fulfilled. Many story arcs are brought to fitting conclusions and heroes are formed and villain's vanquished all with wonderful storytelling and composure in it's final act.

Luke Skywalker's attack on the Death Star marked the conclusion of "Star Wars." We went after Luke and Luke by himself. At the climax of "The Empire Strikes Back," there were two distinct streams of action: Leia and Han fought for their freedom, and Luke Skywalker faced off against Vader. There were three divisions in "Return of the Jedi": Endor, Death Star, and rebel fleet. And guess what? "The Phantom Menace" breaks up the climactic action into FOUR streams. Things will get absurd if this tendency persists. They have already.

It all comes down to the Ewoks: either you're okay with them, or you hate them. For me, they're alright, maybe because I was 9 when I saw this movie on first release. Anyway, if you can get past that, there's a lot to love: epic space battles, Luke's final temptation and showdown with Vader, and the great first act on Tatooine. One gripe: Leia doesn't have much agency in this movie, showing less drive and leadership as she did in the first movies, and showing no hint of the commanding military presence she'd have in the sequels.
Undoubtedly a worthy ending.

Warning: Spoilers So what made this movie a step down than its two predecessors? Well, forgive me for nit picking, but I didn't think the humour is as strong as it was in New Hope and Empire Strikes Back. Plus, while it was evident, the romantic elements weren't as developed either. However, putting these flaws aside, it is still enormously entertaining, thanks to the elaborate set pieces and the well choreographed battles(the final battle especially was a knockout). And I will say that it is a vast improvement over the prequels. The plot is still fast paced and sophisticated, and the screenplay while not as fun still is as imaginative as ever. I have heard many complaints about the Ewoks. I think it depends on your perspective whether you like them or not; maybe a delight to younger audiences, maybe too sickly cute to an adult. Being a 17 year old female, I thought they were very cute. The acting is still very impressive, with Mark Hamill spontaneously likable in the lead. Frank Oz is a perfect Yoda and his death scene is heart rending, and Ian McDairmund also steals his scenes as the Emperor. Harrison Ford, in an inspired bit of casting is great again as Han Solo, Carrie Fisher is still vivacious and Alec Guiness the great actor that he was is brilliant as Obi Wan. But my favourite is James Earl Jones as the voice of Darth Vader, his majestic booming voice is very ideal for a dark menacing villain. And I must mention John Williams's music, brilliant and innovative, unquestionably one of the best film scores of all time. All in all, while my least favourite of the original trilogy, Return of the Jedi makes for essential viewing. 9/10 Bethany Cox.

An EPIC conclusion to the best movie trilogy of all time. We start out strong with the absolutely excellent sequence that is the Battle of the Great Pit of Carkoon. A.k.a. the Sarlaac Pit. The setting of the multiple desert skiffs and Jabba's Sail Barge created an excellent set for an epic battle. Then we finish it off with a final battle so large, that it's on three fronts at the same time. With the Rebel Alliance fighting the Empire in space while they hold out for the ground assault to disable the second Death Star's shield. Meanwhile, we have Han Solo, and Leia Organa leading the Rebels and Ewoks against the Imperial Bunker. Within this battle we've got the Ewoks beating on the legs of the giant AT-STs with small wooden and stone clubs and throwing rocks at Stormtroopers and hijacking the Imperial speeder-bikes. On top of that, we have a fantastic duel of Palpatine manipulating Luke to harness his anger and use it to fight his father. Until he realizes that he's being manipulated and that Palpatine is trying to turn him to the dark side. All of this culminating in Darth Vader making the ultimate sacrifice and throwing the Emperor down a bottomless pit to his death in order to save his son, thus bringing balance to the force and fulfilling his prophecy as the chosen one. 10/10

I think most consider this to be the weakest movie of the original trilogy, and it is, though it's not bad either. It has lost half a star for additions to it post prequel trilogy, one of the worst of which turns that disgusting Sarlacc creature (sand beast that devours people dropped into it) into Audry from the Little Shop of Horrors, and some other additions. I forgot about that particular addition, and it made me rage again upon seeing it when recently watching the movie on Disney+. It's original version was far more impressive, as a giant thorny hole in the sand, and much more menacing as a result. In addition I didn't much care for adjustments to the entertainment in Jaba the Hut's base, those moments seeming to be particularly disjointed. With respects to original elements, the Ewoks, while cute, do seem to be something of a mistake, in that they occupy too much movie time, with no meaningful amount of Ewok character development - there was indeed a regular one that popped up more often than the others, but they didn't go to any lengths to make that really resonate. Endor also seemed a location that had little meaning, in so far as that new death star's development was concerned - I suppose it would have been a tactically discrete location for construction, and testing maybe, but it didn't make all that much sense either, in terms of ramping up the stakes! Had it had its sights set on Tattooine, for example, the stakes may have elevated a good deal more.

Return of the Jedi doesn't seem to be regarded as highly as the first two originals, but it has the phenomenal action and impactful character arcs we love from star wars, as well as one of the best endings to a trilogy‚Äîlet alone a movie‚Äîever. Weirdly enough after watching the original trilogy as a whole I am unsure which I prefer this film or A New Hope but I do have a knack for enjoying the less celebrated Star Wars entries more than the acclaimed films. That being said I despise the sequels but this film was just so much fun. From the opening sequence to the final battle this film was pure satisfaction. That being said I do have my criticisms. I am going to focus on a few topics, the overall vision issues, originality, and what I am going to call the Porg problem. Lets start with the originality, this film features both a new death star complete with another space battle with a satisfying destructive pay off, an opening fight that resolves and sets up parts of the previous film and current film, Luke going to Dagobah and splitting off from Leia and Han, and final fight with Vader, While the destruction of the death star is done better in the first film I will give the film credit the confrontation of Jabba was more entertaining for me then the battle of Hoth and it was a cool way to update the audience on the ways in which the characters have changed. Additionally it was a cool reinvention of Tatooine and an extremely captivating and sleazy environment. The Dagobah scenes are important in shooting the arrow towards Luke's final arc and the showdown with the Emperor and Vader but the reveal of Leia as Luke's sister was however well handled in this film something that should have been chosen from the start because it makes some scenes in previous movies fairly uncomfortable. The final fight with Vader was also reinvented in the most compelling way possible and seeing Luke prove the Emperor wrong was immensely satisfying especially since we have seen him succeed over and over again from the prequels until this point. Now that we have tackled the first two issues I am going to move on to the Porg Problem. I did not hate the Ewok's. They were a strange addition but they were cute. They did feel a little too cartoony at times as well and also it was kind of messed up to see the Ewok's get taken advantage of by the rebels in order to win the battle. They are seduced by C3PO and his stories and essentially become a fan club of soldiers for the rebellion and its really sad especially in one scene to watch an Ewok clutching the body of one of his own. I also found it kind of distasteful to have the them believe C3PO was a god because he is essentially in a position of power over them. Its clear that the film wanted a fuzzy lovable toy selling tribe of Teddy Bears and while I took a great amount of joy watching the Empire get emasculated by a bunch of Care Bears with spears I think it would have been much cooler if instead of Endor the Empire built their base on Kashyyyk. That way we could explore a little bit of Chewbacca's species and history and have his people tear the arms off of some Stormtroopers. It would feel more like they were fighting with a goal in mind and actually have the respect of the rebels rather than be looked down upon plus it would have been pretty awesome. Still the final battles were incredibly satisfying from the Ewok's fighting the Stormtroopers and the destruction of the base, to Lando's assault and destruction of the second death star. But finally this film makes the prequels feel like their actually part of the story and the lore. Luke's showdown with the Emperor is pretty awesome and builds its tension well as we see Luke give in to the dark side but then after cutting off Vader's hand realizes he is becoming like him and turning to the dark side so he unlike his father defeats his temptations and puts his negative emotions aside. Because of this the Emperor tortures and tries to kill Luke but as we know Vader cares about his son even if he won't admit it just as he cared for Padme and in his emotional turmoil destroys the Emperor at the cost of his life. In his last moments he redeems himself thanks to the love he had for his son. The culmination of all three of these moments results in a giant party with fireworks and the conclusions to everyone's arcs as Lando regains cloud city from the Empire. Luke completes his training and becomes a Jedi Knight. Anakin is redeemed by his son and becomes one with the force. Leia and Han resolve all their tension and begin their romance officially and the entire galaxy celebrates their freedom. The film also makes changes to itself to fit into the future films with Anakin's actor in the prequels playing his force ghost and a few added scenes of Coruscant and Naboo. I commend these changes although I can understand why those who hate the prequels and grew up with the original trilogy may despise them. Overall the ending is extremely satisfying and gave me goosebumps. Honestly I received all the closure I needed and this is a perfect end to this trilogy and a perfect end to the saga. Honestly I am not opposed to new Star Wars films but after seeing the original trilogy for the first time in a decade or so I refuse to acknowledge that any of the sequel trilogy exists in this timeline. I loved this movie and despite a few flaws it wrapped up the trilogy with a note of triumph that left me with great happiness.

While this movie isn't as perfect as the first two, it is genuinely excellent, contrary to what many would say (for reasons I'm not entirely sure). The characters are every bit as well-written and likeable as in the preceding films, the story is still engaging (if just a bit thin, as it's ultimately an extended Third Act of the over-arching story), the villains are still immensely intimidating, the music is still wonderful and the action sequences are still awesome. Heck, from an action standpoint, this might be the best of the three, as the Climax is very long, featuring both a Ground Battle and a Space Battle, alongside a third based on Story Resolution, and despite the >30 minute duration, this climax NEVER loses momentum. While this movie doesn't have the depth of the first two, it does escalate everything that worked before, and because of this, the emotional catharsis from the climax of this movie is sublime -- I honestly can't think of any other Action series that ends with such a perfect emotional satisfaction. It's well-written, well-directed and has both adrenaline and sincerity, and apart from an overlong first act, I cannot think of a better way this borderline-perfect Trilogy could have ended.

Now before you rush ahead and quickly mark my review unhelpful, hear me out alright? Return of the Jedi is the only movie of the trilogy I had no hopes from. I had heard of people saying that it's the worst in the series. But considering I got bored from A New Hope and The Empire Strikes Back I thought this one is going to be even worse (why I got bored of them, that's written on their reviews. But still if you're too lazy to check it's because I always somehow get bored watching old movies). So I had absolutely no expectations from it. Turns out it has the most story of all the Star Wars movies. The movie began with answering the question as to what happened to Han Solo. He gets rescued by Luke and Leia. We even get to see the iconic Boba Fett in that scene. Later on we get to see Lando. Even though I haven't heard about him and I actually had to look up his name while writing this review, he looks pretty iconic. I don't know if this was a popular look or this movie made the look popular, but I guess the latter is true. There were many other NPC characters throughout the movie, but for me the selling point were the Ewoks. And I don't care what all the "die-hard Star Wars fanboys" say. The Ewoks are so adorable! I wanted to pull their cheeks. Their scenes were so cute and funny. The way they fought the Stormtroopers or treated C3PO like a messiah was really wholesome. I really wanted to see that kind of stuff in Star Wars movies. Just because it's set in space doesn't mean it always has to blast out laser guns or have huge flying ships. After all, it's set long long ago in a galaxy far far away. There could be many tribes living over there as well. And seeing them hold up makes me believe they still exist somewhere in today's time, having evolved into becoming teddy bears as advanced as humans. And finally Darth Vader's final fight scene in this movie, in my opinion, was way better than The Empire Strikes Back. We actually get to see what Darth Vader looks like, and he hasn't cut Luke's arm for this. This is the correct way of drawing out emotions. The one who is making the audience emotional should be in pain, and not the one being made emotional. Darth Sidious was really intimidating, and I really wanted more of him rather than the trash that Palpatine was. Star Wars: Episode VI is even today my favourite Star Wars movie. It doesn't matter what others say about it, it's gonna be the most OP in my opinon. In just 2.5 hours it managed to tell more story than the entire sequel trilogy combined. And the best part - the spoilers from this movie aren't even as popular as Episode IV or V, so I could watch it without already knowing what I'm about to watch. I'd absolutely watch it again.

7.25/10. 'Return of the Jedi' is the weakest of the original Star Wars films. Where the first two pushed boundaries and innovated, 'Return of the Jedi' was content to do little more than end the story in uninspired - albeit entertaining - fashion. There isn't anything inherently wrong with making a simple, breezy, popcorn-ready flick, but being anything less than ground-breaking like it's predecessors were is a recipe for disappointment. The plot doesn't seem to have any forward thrust; after a thrilling first act, the story settles into well-troden territory by following the blueprint of 'A New Hope' - a gang of rebels must defeat the empire and it's giant destructo-ship. It's unfortunate that the creativity and character development from 'The Empire Strikes Back' couldn't carry over. The movie was still quite entertaining, as any fan of the effects-driven action sequences, so viscerally brought to life by a top-notch technical crew, can attest. Another familial twist and the final redemption arc that sees peace restored to the galaxy are interesting nuggets, and Ian McDiarmid as the Emperor is a scene stealer. 'RotJ' wraps up this trilogy with technical wizardry and fun, but opted for safe, crowd pleasing mundanity instead of creative daring. It could and should have been much more, but ultimately stands as a testament to the complacency that often follows success, and foreshadows the overarching creative issues found in Lucas' prequel trilogy.

The first decision in this movie made by Luke to risk sacrificing his loyal druids was very weird and questionable to me. Also, the plan to rescue Han felt really weird, it was very uncoordinated. The death of Boba Fett was unspectacular and disappointing, a really good built-up character died within seconds. Overall I liked the battle at Jabbas basement. The first 40 minutes are really well done. Luke making it up to Han, which saved him just like he did in this movie. A really good callback. Yoda¬¥s passing scene together with Luke was very sweet, and a great way to say goodbye to an iconic character. Seeing the group of Han, Leia, Luke, Chewie, R2D2, and C3-PO going for possibly one last adventure was great and a real nostalgic factor, which I totally loved. On a critical note, I have to add the speeder fights, which did not age well at all. The fight in itself wasn't that bad, but the pictures and effects looked very bad, just signs of the time. I dug the whole jungle set, though, which in my opinion were a good different location compared to the other movies. R2D2 once again saving the group by helping them to escape from the trap in the jungle was another proof that R2D2 is the goat. C3PO being the god of the Ewoks was a bit weird at first, but I liked it in the end. Luke¬¥s reveal that Leia is his sister felt very well done and well-written. In another epic moment, Luke first meets Darth Sidious which was a super important moment, and felt like that, too. I was not the biggest fan of the fact that 6 guys and a group of Ewoks are equal in a battle against AT-STs and a couple of hundred stormtroopers. Really epic was the fight between Luke and Darth Vader though. And it felt like it's a tradition to lose an arm in a battle in Star Wars. Vader finally betraying Sidious felt soo good and also was great as a moment. The space battles in the last act are visually spectacular reflecting back to this time. Anakin's goodbye to Luke was emotional by a well-surrounded score, lovely moment. I loved the look on Han¬¥s face when Leia told him that Luke is her brother, brilliant. It was a brilliant way to end this trilogy, I really loved it.

Review: While it suffers from plodding first and second acts, Return of the Jedi features possibly the best Star Wars third act of all time. The ewok battle goes on too long, but the Death Star space battle is amazing and visually marvellous, and everything in the Emperors Throne Room is incredible, best of the franchise stuff. The music is still great, and the sets and effects are great, but the story does become episodic, with some weak pacing in the Ewok Village and Jabba's Palace. However, its always entertaining and rewatchable, and for all its flaws, Return of the Jedi is still a great adventure and a throughly satisfying end to the Original trilogy, with many best of the franchise moments. | Grade: B+
